body.p:
Frankfort Oct. 23rd 1863
To his Excellency Gov. Bramlette
On the day of 186 Graham Akin of Danville, a youth of about 14 years of age, very delicate & slender, was attending the school of a Mr Waterman in the city of Frankfort Ky.
Thomas Davenport, about the age of 17 or 18 years, Heavy & stout, was attending the same school.

Akin was swinging in the gymnasium when he was interrupted in his exercise by Davenport standing in the way of the swing. Akin requested Davenport to move and not obstruct him which Davenport refused to do; Akin continued his exercises and slightly brushed against Davenport, where-upon Davenport Choaked and otherwise maltreated Akin, who, suffering from the severity of Davenport's treatment, rushed into the house of Mr Waterman, sized his gun and shot Davenport with small shot.

Akin was indited by the "Grand Jury" of Franklin Co. at its June session in 1863 for "shooting, in sudden heat and passion, on Thomas Davenport, with intent to kill" Akin was held to bail in the sum of $60000 to appear at the next October term
of said court, to answer with the Commonwealth of Ky as stated in the indictment.

He appeared and in open court on the 12th day of October 1863 and on the 21st day of October 1863 was arraigned and plead "Guilty" to the indictment. The Jury accordingly returned a verdict of "Guilty" assessing his fine at fifty ($50) Dollars.
Deeming this to be a case in which your leniency would be well exercised, We therefore pray you to remit the fine.

P. U. Major
W. H. Sneed
Jno. M. Hewitt Jr.

Franklin Cir Ct
vs
Graham Akin

Remit all except fees & costs.
Oct 24th 1863
Tho. E. Bramlette
$50 --
Shooting
